utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: And the only thing wrong – the only thing wrong with the American dream is people. Too many people. Too many of us telling young people that the dream is dead. They told me that when I was growing up in the slums of Trenton, and they were wrong. They told me that when I decided to run for Senator with only $58 in my savings account and they were wrong! And they are still telling me that now, that I don’t have a chance: because I’m black, because I don’t have the right nose, because I still have only $58 in my savings account. With your help, we can keep that dream alive. And in closing – – just… let me say…

utterance.speaker: Staffer
utterance.content: Let ME say that you should all donate the legal maximum to the next President of the United States! Are you okay, do you need some water or something?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: No, no, I’m fine, I’m fine, really.

utterance.speaker: Union Guy
utterance.content: A handsome guy like you, I bet you get 70% of the women.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Heh, here’s hoping.

utterance.speaker: Union Guy
utterance.content: Of course, it helps your wife died of cancer. I mean, I’m sorry, but the sympathy vote’s in your pocket.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Yeah, I appreciate your support.

utterance.speaker: Union Guy
utterance.content: Listen, Senator, my union has a hell of a war chest.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Um, I’ve always been strong on the union.

utterance.speaker: Union Guy
utterance.content: The thing is, you always go on in your speeches about the workers in Indonesia, Cambodia, Timbuktu –

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Because I think we have… a moral, uh –

utterance.speaker: Union Guy
utterance.content: My union members are hurting. They don’t care about moral this or moral that. Are you all right?

utterance.speaker: Various staffers
utterance.content: Senator?

utterance.speaker: Union Guy
utterance.content: Hey! The guys are gonna love that.

utterance.speaker: Various staffers
utterance.content: Tell him to breathe! Give him some room! Senator, are you all right?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: The Senator’s suffering from nausea, headache, and mental confusion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, bad sushi is so hard to diagnose.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: You’re being childish. Look, if his case is as trivial as you think it’ll take you three minutes to diagnose him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh huh, three minutes that I could spend sitting on the toilet with the funny pages.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: You’re mad at me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. I never liked Cameron or Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Do you know why I’m forcing you to fire one of them? Because you need to prove to me that you’re a team player. Now, if you did that, you wouldn’t need to go through this exercise.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I’ll hold the Senator’s hair while he upchucks.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Oh, and by the way, I need you to give a speech at the National Cardiology Conference. Next week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t do speeches. I’m shy.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Eastbrook Pharmaceuticals has developed a new ACE inhibitor. I would like you to extol the virtues of this breakthrough medication.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eastbrook Pharmaceuticals… wait a second, don’t I own that company? Oh, no, that’s right, you do.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Viopril is a significant improvement over the old version. All there in the study.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know its price tag is significantly improved.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: You can either give one ten minute talk and one three minute diagnosis or you can fire one of your pets. My understanding was that you believed in rationality above all else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Viopril…

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I appreciate your keeping the media way.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re keeping your staff away as well. You’re taking it easy, now.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I’m in the middle of a campaign.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The faster we can get you better, the faster you can get out of here. Anyone else at the fundraiser get sick?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I don’t think so. And I don’t think that’s it, I’ve been under the weather for weeks, you know. Lots of traveling, supposed to be in the Sudan next week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Helps me concentrate. Even better than drugs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Open your mouth, please. That’s quite a scar.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: When I was six, I fell off the swings and bit my tongue. Couldn’t talk right for the longest time. Lots of teasing. But, you know, it just made me fight harder, speak up for those who can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Tongues heal too fast. Your political consultants have written you a nice story. In a tight race the lispers alone could put you over the top.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: You a Republican, or you just hate all politicians?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just find being forced to sit through drivel annoying.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: You find sincerity annoying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re a black kid from the ghetto who made it to Yale Law and the United States Senate. That’s a sufficiently mythical story, you don’t need to lie about your tongue. Must have missed it.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: What’s wrong? What is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not the food. It’s your brain. Get an MRI and a lumbar puncture. Cancel your travel plans.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The LP showed no sign of infection and the MRI was fairly clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I guess we can tell him he’s fairly healthy and can go home.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, there is something in Broca’s area, but it’s small, low intensity.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Most likely just background nose.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Care to bet your job on that? What was that?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What was what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You got annoyed. That was clearly an annoyed face.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I get annoyed by glib remarks about our futures.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But last week you didn’t get annoyed, you made poopie in your pants. It’s weird, it’s almost like now you know you have nothing to worry about.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Chase has nothing to worry about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: None of you has anything to worry about.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Vogler saw the error of his ways and repented. The lesion could be nothing. It could also be a brain tumor or infection. There’s only one way to find out which.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You wanna cut into his brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dangerous, I know. Especially as he’s a politician, his brain’s all twisted. But I weighed that against the risk of him stroking out before lunch. Call surgery, get it scheduled.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re not pregnant.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Well, I told you that. But there’s gotta be some other reason I’m still spotting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. You were pregnant. Based on your hormone levels, you had a miscarriage.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I haven’t even been on a date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, since it’s physically impossible to have sex without someone buying you dinner.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I haven’t had sex since I split up with my husband. That was almost a year ago.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine, have it your way. Immaculate conception.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Um, what do I do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, it’s obvious. Start a religion. [He leaves. As he walks out, Cuddy storms past him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: In my office.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Afternoon delight. She just loves the hard wood.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not doing a brain biopsy on a spot on a MRI.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where’d you get that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not on an United States Senator.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, just so I’m clear, if he was a janitor, that would be okay. Do you have a list?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A brain biopsy can cause permanent neurological damage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh huh, whereas tumors are really good for brains, make ‘em grow big and strong. It’s my call.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, it’s not.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re pulling rank on patient care?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s not my call, either.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s up to you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either it’s a tumor or it’s an infection that the lumbar puncture didn’t pick up. Either way, if we don’t treat it immediately, it could kill you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Or it could be nothing. Reading brain MRIs is not an exact science.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: W-what caused my s-symptoms?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow, excellent question. Many doctors wouldn’t have gone there.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It could be a transient ischemic attack. You could make the argument for watching carefully for the time being.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mmm, but you’d only make that argument if you were an administrator covering your own ass.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s absurd, and insulting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Insulting, yes.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: W-what will the voters think? If they find out I’ve had a b-brain biopsy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This could leave you b-b-b-b-brain damaged, and you’re worried about NASCAR dads?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not a brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not a bacterial infection, either.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So you biopsied his brain for nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If that were true, would Dr. Wilson’s mouth be contorted into that ugly little shape?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s toxoplasmosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You sure?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means the Great Black Hope has full-blown AIDS. They’re gonna love that in Dubuque.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Toxoplasmosis is a fairly common fungus you can get from eating undercooked meat or touching cat feces. In rare cases the fungi travel up the blood stream and into the brain causing a lesion or inflammation.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: So, what’s the prognosis?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Toxo usually responds to treatment, but it only causes a lesion in your brain if your immune system is extremely weak to begin with. Senator, I’m afraid you have AIDS. As I’m sure –

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: As I’m sure you know, people with HIV can live a long time.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: What else could do this to me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Theoretically, certain cancers –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you have toxo in your brain, you have AIDS.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I do not have AIDS. I don’t sh-sh-shoot up drugs, I don’t sl-sleep with…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is very bad news. I get that, and I sympathize. But we’ve gotta speed through the denial phase because you need antiretrovirals and you need them fast.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: You haven’t even tested me for HIV!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We will.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But the toxo drugs are going to piss off your fungi, and when fungi get pissed –

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I am not gonna take the pills.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re afraid word will leak out. Trust me, you’re not going to become President either way. They don’t call it the White House because of the paint job.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Here’s what you’re gonna do. You’re going to give me the drugs for the toxo only. You are going to test me for HIV under a false name. You are going to test me for cancer and anything else that could have done this to me. If I have cancer, I will deal with it, but I do not have AIDS.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: “Eastbrook Pharmaceuticals are pleased to announce that Dr. Gregory House will present the latest research on their exciting new ACE inhibitor.”

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re making that up. That’s Vogler’s company.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Press release. Doing an address at the North American Cardiology Conference.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: House never gives speeches.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But when I really believe in something… Gosh dang it, I’ve got a chance to make a difference here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You made a deal with Vogler?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s all the rage. Everybody’s doing it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So, what’s the deal? You get to keep all of us if you plug his products?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One speech, no biggie. Foreman’s doing a bone marrow biopsy to check for cancer.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cancer? The Senator’s got AIDS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cancer sounds better on a press release. I need you guys to rush the ELISA test for HIV.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thank you. For the speech.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When I said rush, I meant, you know, fast. Stat’s the word you doctors use, right?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know it’s hard for you –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Double stat?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This may sting a little. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: It wasn’t the shot, it’s, um, my head, it’s killing me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You know, Senator, we don’t have to do this now. We can wait until your HIV test comes back.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Guess you figure it’s gonna come back positive.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, in my experience –

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Patients lie. Politicians lie more. And black politicians –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Whoa, I don’t think black politicians lie more than white politicians.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: We lie less.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You figure we’re morally superior?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I’ve got my theories. No, we, we just can’t get away with it. No one’s gonna gi-give us the benefit of the doubt. No one’s gonna cut us a second chance. And, and when it happens it’s not just a bad politician, it’s, it’s, it’s a bad role model, it’s a dis-discredit to the race. You ready?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah. Take a deep breath.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House. I just wanted to –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re welcome, again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I want you to know how much I –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got it. You’re grateful. Apparently you seem to think it’ll mean a lot to me to know that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you know why people believe in God?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought you didn’t believe in God.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, then you better be making a very good point.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you think they pray to Him and praise Him because they want Him to know how great He is? God already knows that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you comparing me to God? I mean, that’s great, but just so you know, I’ve never made a tree.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I thank you because it means something to me. To be grateful for what I receive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You are the most naïve atheist I’ve ever met.

utterance.speaker: Clinic nurse
utterance.content: Dr. House, you have a patient in Room One.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank God. People pray so that God won’t crush them like bugs. I’m not gonna crush you.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Petechial bruising? I don’t know if I’m pronouncing that right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gosh, the internet is such a wonderful tool.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: It could be leukemia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Definitely possible. The more likely diagnosis is hickey.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Well, it can’t be a hickey.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why is everybody so ashamed of sex all of a sudden?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I’m not having sex. I’ve barely even thought about sex since my marriage. Ow!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I say you’re having sex, you say you’re not. Either you’re lying, or I’m wrong. Or there’s some middle ground.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: You mean like oral?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I mean you’re having sex without knowing it. I’m testing you for booze, drugs and GHB.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I don’t drink, and… what’s GHB?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The date rape drug.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s positive. Your T-cell count is eight, which means there’s a good chance you’ll die. I’m telling you this because we need to contact your sexual partners.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I’ve only had two girlfriends. Two, after my wife died. I used c-c-condoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know the chances of you getting HIV from heterosexual sex with a condom?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Some day there will be a black president. Some day there will be a gay president. Maybe there will even be a gay, black president. But one combination I do not see happening is gay, black, and dead. You need to stop lying to me.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: It must be miserable, always assuming the worst in people.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, cut the crap, you’re dying.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: You’re clever, you’re witty, and you are a coward! You’re scared of taking chances.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I take chances all the time, it’s one of my worst qualities.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: On people?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wanting to believe the best about people doesn’t make it true.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Being afraid to believe it doesn’t make it false.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, that’s very moving. It’s a shame I don’t vote.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: This is who I am. I believe in people. I’m not hiply cynical and I don’t make easy, snide remarks. I would rather think that people are good and be disappointed once and again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need to draw some more blood.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: NURSE!!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The antiretrovirals aren’t working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not surprising.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He’s just going to keep getting worse. You realize that, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you spying on my case?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why are you giving that speech next week? We’re both just doing what we have to do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you don’t see a problem with that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Checking in on a patient? Yeah, wow, how do I look myself in the mirror?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re not the one being asked to perpetrate a fraud on the American people.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s a ten minute speech!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That I’ve been ordered to give.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Vogler’s drug works!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t care.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, why do you have to make everything so dramatic?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I’m a very high-strung little lapdog. Ruff ruff ruff, rarr, ruff!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nuh uh. No pills.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: What’s going on?!?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The antiretrovirals aren’t working.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because you don’t have AIDS. The first test was a false positive. Happens one time in every five thousand.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: You r-ran a second test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. You’re still dying. The only difference is now we don’t know why.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s continuing to lose control of the muscles on his right side, his brain is getting foggier, and his T-cells are in the single digits.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why are we doing this here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So Cuddy can’t find us. Unless we find out the underlying disease, this guy’s lied to his last constituent.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: False negative on the PCR AIDS test?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ran it twice.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Immunoglobulin deficiency?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No history of respiratory problems.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Idiopathic T-cell deficiency.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Idiopathic, from the Latin meaning we’re idiots ‘cause we can’t figure out what’s causing it. Give him a whole body scan.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You hate whole body scans.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: ‘Cause they’re useless. Could probably scan everyone of us and find five different doodads that look like cancer. But, when you’re 4th-down, 100 to go, in the snow, you don’t call a running play up the middle. Unless you’re the Jets.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I hate sports metaphors.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why did you order the second AIDS test?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Standard procedure.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, well, that’s you. Mr. Standard Procedure. You suspected the first test was a false positive?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I knew he was going to Africa and I figured he was vaccinated for Hep A and B. That could cause a false positive.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, but you knew that before you ordered the first test. What changed?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I should have ordered both.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You were sure he had AIDS, then you talked to him, then you had doubts. What, what did he say?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He said he had not engaged in any risky behavior.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Huh. And you believed him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, he didn’t have any reason to lie –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Everybody lies, except politicians? House, I do believe you’re a romantic. You didn’t just believe him, you believed in him. Do you want to come over tonight and watch old movies and cry? Dr. Cameron’s getting to you. Well, I guess you can’t be around that much niceness and not get any on you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that why you haven’t put the moves on her?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What makes you think I haven’t put the moves on her? Oh. Oh, boy! You’re in trouble.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have restored my faith in the human race. You’re lying.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: No, I’m not lying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just got your results back. No GHB, no nothing. It means you’re having sex, and you’re lying about it.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: No, and I have a new symptom. I have a rash on my butt. Do you want to… What is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s a carpet burn.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: No! It can’t be! Doctor, I love sex. I miss it. I haven’t had any in over a year.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: No, I just wake up really exhausted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is something upsetting you?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: No. My ex lives in the apartment downstairs. He’s always calling me, always wanting to get back together, complaining about mixed signals. Get out of my life, how much clearer can you get?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We have a sleep lab in the basement. If nothing else, it’ll get you away from your ex for a night.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Slightly enlarged lymph node in his left armpit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How slightly?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Quarter mil.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Lymphoma?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, or he’s had a cold in the last six months. What, you’ve got her on speed dial?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I just follow the scent of arrogance.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Another slightly enlarged node over here. Two more in his neck and one in his groin.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And there’s a cyst in his liver.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Looks complex. Central necrosis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Spontaneous bleeding, it’s benign. I was rooting for a really cool tumor, instead we’re stuck with this crap.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Doesn’t matter. Once you find ‘em, you’ve gotta check ‘em.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, knock yourselves out.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I just saw Senator Wright, he looks like hell. That sushi must have been a lot worse than you thought.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mr. Vogler, would you like a free whole body scan? A man of your stature should get himself checked at least three times a year.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Here’s a few key points I want you to cover during your speech.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fourteen pages. The audience will be comatose by paragraph two.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Throw in a joke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Chase. We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do you see this ending?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What ending?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t fire you, so you have no reason to fear me, and therefore no reason to lie to me. You told Cuddy where I was. You told Vogler what I was doing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So how can I work with you?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, you don’t have a choice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This might hurt a little.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Lie to me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay. It’ll, uh, feel like a gentle massage.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: House is a lousy teacher. You can’t lie for beans.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Have you ever told any really big ones?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Oh, ho, I might be messed up, but I’m not that out of it, no no no no no…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Strap his arm down.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Am I gonna be okay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I hope so.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am selling my soul.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Just a little piece. And you are getting something in return.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said I was selling it. I didn’t say I was giving it away. That would be immoral, and stupid. All they’ve done is added antacid.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Does it work?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not the point!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, of course it’s the point! He’s not asking you to lie, he’s not asking you to do something illegal –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s not asking me to do anything.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s not ordering you. He gave you a choice. You chose your staff. I know this isn’t easy for you. You’ll suffer. Vicodin sales in Jersey will triple. But you are doing a good thing. Only you could feel like crap for doing something good.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kidney and liver cysts are both benign, and lymph nodes all came back clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His left armpit node has antibodies for CB 11.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, not enough to indicate lymphoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We never tested for hairy-cell leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, but we would have picked it up somewhere besides one lymph node.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And his spleen isn’t enlarged.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Size isn’t everything. The spleen is the mother lode for hairy-cells. Let’s cut it open.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You can’t biopsy his spleen. It’ll bleed like –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: In the Senator’s condition, a spleen biopsy could easily cause sepsis and kill him!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why do you do this to me? Now, if I kill him, I can’t tell the judge I had no idea of the risks involved.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His brain’s turning into mush, and he’s at risk for more infections, so we have to do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, that’ll sound much better in court. Okay, go tell our human pincushion we’ll be sticking him one more time. Cuddy. Don’t you hate doing this?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What’s up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You like me. Why?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s kind of a sad question.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just trying to figure out what makes you tick. I am not warm and fuzzy and you are basically a stuffed animal made by grandma.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t think that’s why you’re asking. I think it’s because of the speech.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh God, don’t try and pick me apart.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then why are you asking? What do you want to hear?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, Senator. We need to do one more biopsy, on your spleen.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I’ll have to sign lefty, my fingers aren’t working.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’ve been coughing a lot? Does it hurt?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: It’s like I can’t get air. Is that from the toxo?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, this is, this is new. You don’t need to sign, we can’t do the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The Senator’s breathing is severely impaired. His O2 stat levels are at 89. His silver stain indicates pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Another killer fungus. It’s consistent with hairy-cell leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But we can’t biopsy his spleen. Respiratory distress? His platelets are 20 and dropping, his blood won’t clot worth a damn.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s gotta be another way to diagnose hairy-cell.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, his bone marrow’s indeterminate, spleen’s the only way to go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, when the Inuit go fishing, they don’t look for fish.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why, Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They look for the blue heron, because there’s no way to see the fish. But if there’s fish, there’s gonna be birds fishing. Now, if he’s got hairy-cell, what else are we gonna see circling overhead?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He should have all sorts of weird viruses.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: HTLV and ATLV.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We can test for them. Run the titers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: These were your brain waves at 2:45 AM. Now, here it comes, there’s an abrupt jump from slow-wave sleep. This indicates partial sleep arousal. The most common type is somnambulism – sleepwalking.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: That would explain why I’m so tired when I wake up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, and also why you were pregnant. And the hickies. And the carpet burn.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I had sex in my sleep?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sexsomnia is a documented disorder. You said your ex lives downstairs –

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I’ll kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, but he probably didn’t know that you were asleep. Sexsomniacs can act pretty normal. I’m going to write you a prescription for a low-dose antidepressant. It’ll let you sleep better. If you want to save yourself the $15 co-pay, you can have sex while you’re awake.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: He’s my ex, I –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You live in the same building, you haven’t had sex with anyone else for a year, you sleepwalk right into his arms. Call me crazy, but I’m sensing unresolved issues.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Negative for HTLV-1 and 2 and ATLV and everything else. It’s not hairy-cell. Hey. You really gonna give that speech?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve got an opinion, too?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m a little surprised. Frankly, I thought you were too much of a self-absorbed ass to do this for us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re welcome. He’s positive for Epstein-Barr.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So what? It doesn’t point to hairy-cell, it’s irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn’t fall off the swings when you were eight.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Six!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ever.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Give that back!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh uh. We have to talk. You had an epileptic seizure. That’s how you bit your tongue.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: I haven’t had a seizure since I was –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What medication did you take?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: No seizure since I was six. No drugs since I was ten!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s it. Don’t worry about what the question is, don’t worry that you’re starting to feel dizzy, just stay on message.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: My mother used to call it physofin –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Phenytoin?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Yeah! Okay, okay, you’re okay, it’s okay. Everybody lies.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: CVID? That’s a type of immunoglobulin deficiency. I said that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, well, it was a stupid idea when you said it. Then he got the respiratory problem and tested positive for Epstein-Barr.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s pretty much a childhood disease.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Another reason why Chase’s suggestion was idiotic. He got it when he was a kid. Didn’t get any symptoms until now, it happens. It gets triggered by stress, like public speaking.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So you’re basing your diagnosis on a disease that’s relatively common and a drug he took thirty years ago.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start the senator on IV immunoglobulin stat. If he gets better, I’m right, if he dies, you’re right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You faked that.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Say “antiretroviral”.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Antiretroviral.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now say it three times fast.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We just got back your latest blood results. Your white cells are up, your T-cells are back over 100.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Well, that’s good, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In a week? That’s terrific. You’ll need medication for the rest of your life, but other than that, you’re fine.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Am I well enough to run for president?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, why not run for pope while you’re at it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, come on. Kennedy had Addison’s, FDR had polio. Two of the best presidents in the last hundred years –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If they were running today they wouldn’t stand a chance.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: So, you figure you’d be Surgeon General if you didn’t have the limp.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, there’s things I can’t do, and like you said, I have to live with reality.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Well, then I’m running.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Good for you.

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: No, don’t get excited, he’s right, I, uh, I won’t win.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then why run?

utterance.speaker: Senator
utterance.content: Oh, I see, your point being the only way to make a difference is to win every fight.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: But hey, why listen to me? I own the company, I’m certainly not to be trusted, right? Dr. Gregg House, on the other hand, has a reputation. For integrity, among other things. Ladies and gentlemen, Dr. Gregg House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eastbrook Pharmaceuticals’ extraordinary commitment to research excellence is exemplified by their new ACE inhibitor, a breakthrough medical approach that will protect millions from heart disease.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: That’s not a speech.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought it was pithy. You got enough for a press release, anyhow.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Foreman or Cameron?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A few things I forgot to mention. Ed Vogler is a brilliant businessman. A brilliant judge of people, and a man who has never lost a fight. You know how I know the new ACE inhibitor is good? Because the old one was good. The new one is really the same, it’s just more expensive. A lot more expensive. See, that’s another example of Ed’s brilliance. Whenever one of his drugs is about to lose its patent he has his boys and girls alter it just a tiny bit and patent it all over again. Making not just a pointless new pill, but millions and millions of dollars. Which is good for everbody, right? The patients, pish. Who cares, they’re just so damn sick! God obviously never liked them anyway. All the healthy people in the room, let’s have a big round of applause for Ed Vogler! I threw in a joke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I should have taken a couple of extra Vicodin and just held my nose.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m guessing you did take a couple extra Vicodin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don’t need to worry about firing anyone. I’m leaving.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why? Is this another noble, self-sacrificing gesture? You trying to protect Foreman?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So this is just, “Don’t fire me, I quit.”

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m protecting myself. You asked me why I like you. You’re abrasive and rude, but I figured everything you do, you do it to help people. But I was wrong. You do it because it’s right. There are only two ways I can deal with things. One is in my control. That’s to leave. Goodbye, House.
